newsitem.title: USA: Atlantic Energy proposes limited rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Atlantic Energy proposes limited rate cut.

text.p: Atlantic Energy Inc said Tuesday it proposed a five percent rate reduction as a first step toward a restructured electric utility industry.
The proposal was included in the filing its Atlantic Electric subsidary made with the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities in response to the board's proposal for electric industry restructuring.
The two-phase rate cut, based on 1996 rates, includes a reduction of about one percent when regulatory approval is received for the Atlantic Energy and Delmarva Power and Light Co merger.
Another estimated four percent reduction would begin in the year 2001, related to other reductions in operating costs.
"We view these projected rate reductions as a reasonable first step toward a restructured electric utility industry," said Jerry Jacobs, chief executive of Atlantic Energy.

"In a few years, people will look back and evaluate the quality of decisions regulators, utilities and legislators made. They will not judge how fast the industry was redesigned," Jacobs said. "They will ask if consumers and New Jersey are better off."
The company said its filing accepts the board's proposal to phase-in customer choice of power suppliers beginning with 10 percent of supplies in October 1998.
Jacobs emphasized the need for full recovery of transitional -- or stranded -- costs, that is those costs incurred to comply with regulatory mandates.
Atlantic Electric's filing estimated its transitional costs are estimated to be about $1.3 billion, with $965 million or 75 percent is attributable to non-utility generation contracts.

The utility said these contracts are the result of both federal and state public policy to stimulate the growth of non-utility generators -- or NUGs -- as mandated by the 1978 Public Utilities Regulatory Policy Act.
"If Atlantic could buy the power we have to take from the NUGs in the open market, Atlantic's customers would save millions of dollars over the life of the contracts," Jacobs noted.
While negotiations with some of the company's NUGs have resulted in savings, the contracts are still substantially over market, Jacobs said.
He stressed that Atlantic is committed to continue working with the NUGs to renegotiate these over-market contracts and to try to solve this problem.

"If there ever was a time to challenge the NUG owners to come to the table and negotiate a reduction of these contracts, it is now when the BPU is working to restructure New Jersey's entire electric utility industry," Jacobs stressed. "Atlantic would like to join the NUGs in a search for the proverbial 'win-win' situation and pass these savings along to our customers."
The filing says "we are going to attempt to renegotiate the NUG contracts to lower costs," Senior Vice President for External Affairs Henry Levari told Reuters.
However, he continued, the company would still prefer to buy out these contracts and securitize the buy-out costs.

He noted Atlantic Electric's projected rate reductions do not include any of the benefits securitization would produce, pointing out legislation is needed before costs can be securitized in New Jersey.
Levari said Atlantic Electric has already placed its generating facilities in a separate subsidiary which its filing proposes would be deregulated.
